Freedom has come at unfathomable costs.  Since the first ships arrived on the shores, there have been an uncountable number of events that have led up to this very moment.  A lot of events documented, or at least still existent within the history of 'western civilization,' but a lot of them have been either completely disregarded, or simply changed to make a much better story to tell the kids.  Clearly I cannot verify that as fact, but logic tells you it happened, and on more than one occasion.

Now on to the point.  At first, our civilization was established in a way that is more than deplorable.  Everyday we disregard blatant facts, that stare us directly in the face.  Maybe not literally, per se, but the facts are there it's all about how you see it.  We built our early civilization on small wars with the people that naturally owned this land, we murdered, raped, and slaughtered them, we destroyed their food supplies, means of warmth, and housing, and all for what?  Simply put, GREED.  You can take your pretentious, and fabricated of "Thanksgiving" and shove it up your ass, because when you sit down at the table to eat your food, the last thing you're thinking about is the poor people that were murdered, and now shoved onto reservations, doing slave work no one else will do any more, getting paid shit money, with only the advantage of making casino money, as if that's any consolation.

Next, you have to think about our Revolutionary War.  Now if you understand my sentiments above, you will realize why I speak of this the way I do.  Otherwise, you're just simply an idiot.  Anyhow, our Revolutionary War started with both acts of treason, and acts of terrorism.  One can argue that these acts were not treason, or terrorism, but by definition, they were, revolution or not.  Our country was under the reign of Britain, whose royalty was our acting government.  Settlers were fed up with taking shit from people that didn't even inhabit the land, and so they began revolting, which in turn, started a full blown war.  However, as much as it is depicted with the Revolutionary Soldiers standing on one side, and the "Red Coats" (British/English) on the other.  It's not to say this didn't happen, but if you'd actually look further into the facts, and writings from people at the time, you will notice that this was not always fact.  But in reality, there were plenty of instances, including a specific battle in New Jersey, where "American" soldiers would actually sneak up at night, and visciously kill British soldiers while they slept, or least expected it.  At least from the specific one in mind, these attacks were strategically premeditated, and for the time, acts of terrorism.  The same acts we condemn, are a large part of the birth of our country, and yet since "the past is the past" we repress that, and ignore it, while we become completely hipocritical, and arrogant, speaking outward in complete outrage.  Is it all of the above? Yes.  But to come off as though these same, but less modern acts, were acceptable at a time where our biggest problem was a fucking TEA TAX.  Sure there was more to it than that, but one of the most notable events was a revolt on a tea tax.  Now as this proves further how just hipocritical our government is, upon winning the Revolutionary War no more than two years later were there Tax collectors walking door to door collecting income taxes, and property taxes from the citizens.

Now here I have to ask, was it really the issues with PAYING the taxes, or was it really that it was such a great idea, they wished they had thought of it first? Or moreso that they just wanted a piece of the action?  Not to mention the notable quote in our Declaration Of Independance, which simply says "The best government, is a government which governs least."  Yet thinking of that today, i'd think we don't quite have the government he had in mind at the time.  But hey, maybe I'm just being American and completely misinterpreting plain english.  I suppose that's what happens when you allow your government to get away with using twists on words to falsely portray things, and mislead you into believing something completely different than what is actual fact.  

So then, a hundred or so years later, we had the industrial revolution.  For the first time in history, human beings themselves had actually become a commodity.  We put a pricetag on peoples work efforts, and basically bought their work for next to nothing in most cases.  This is where everything took a turn for the worst.  We developed an economy, which sooner than later, would basically become the basis for everything.  If the economy does bad, everyone does bad, except for the people whom sit atop of it all.  Yeah, they're doing bad.  But only making 6 billion dollars a week, instead of 30 billion in the oil industry (speaking of the time) I wouldn't really consider to be the biggest hit when you're sitting on more money than all of the people that work(ed) for you combined.  And so, some years later what happens?  A depression occurs, and lasts roughly a decade.  For ten years or so, hard working people struggled, because the economy we thought was so very fit, fell apart almost completely.  As the old saying goes, "A recession is when someone on your street loses your job, a depression is when you, and your neighbor lose your jobs" or at least something to that extent.  In a time where people were lucky to make 20 dollars a week, they were suffering inflation prices that we see today.  You can bet your ass there were plenty of children that starved to death, and a lot worse.  But since we were so convinced that a capitalistic society, based almost completely around an economy created by the government, that we, instead of rethinking our decision to do so, thought of a way to make it work.  And so, we've gone 70 years without a depression.  But have skipped across the top with quite a number of recessions, one of which we're still hovering above at this very moment.  Now, with our wonderful idea of an economy, and the technological advancements of the 90's, the flood of new E-markets, and computer technology on the rise, everywhere, we have become very much reliant on the success of these things.  So in order to keep things going, we promote consumerism, which in turn has created a severe crisis of materialism, and again, in turn, has created a society that is more worried about what they want materially, instead of what they want governmentally, and most importantly.  So many people have begun to ignore politics, and government, because they have had so many things make their lives "easier", that if it's not easy enough to comprehend, than its not worth paying attention to, because we're American, and depth is something we lost a long, long, time ago.

But some people like to take advantage of their freedoms, we have people everyday prancing around the streets using their constitutionally given rights to express themselves, and speak freely of their opinions.  But a lot of these people are under the impression that, just because they have this given right, that their opinions, whether singluarly, or in a group, it should affect everyone.  And alot of these same people, base their beliefs off of the Bible, or some other kind of cult-like religious book.  Besides the fact, religion has absolutely no true place in the political process, who the fuck is supposed to take these people seriously?  You won't oppose your standing government, whose reign has come closer and closer to tyrannical, and oppressive, but you'll oppose something from a book that you can't even prove is actual fact because none of the shit in it actually exists.  Maybe my view on religion is getting in the way here, but regardless, how do you ignore material proof on one thing that is current, but bend over backwards and protest infront of abortion clinics, because some unseen 'GOD' made you believe that this is wrong.  Even if abortion IS wrong, and SHOULD be banned, which it shouldn't, but for fucks sake, lets say thats a fact.  Then how is it that you support war?  How is it that you support a government that has suspectedly used Population Control procedures throughout the past few decades?  If you want to save lives, why are you protesting abortions?  Something tells me HIV/AIDS kills more people a year than abortions do.  Oh wait, is it because you're still under the belief that premarital sex is wrong, and it's a GAY disease?  The same people that preach how great God's morals are, and how all encompassing he is, condemn certain types of people, and stereotype a disease that was aimed specifically at least desireable groups of people as a form of reducing the population so that we do not waste the worlds resources.  Call it a conspiracy theory, or check the facts for yourself AIDS is not some rare disease.  It didn't just magically appear.  According to my limited knowledge, I believe most diseases evolve from others, and so on.  Is it not the least bit ironic that suddenly there was a case of AIDS, then just as suddenly specific groups of people were affected by it?  Contrary to popular belief, homosexual "sodomy" doesn't create the AIDS virus or HIV, and is absolutely no different that having anal intercourse with a woman.  Which of course, just further proves my point on the Governmental way of misleading the public with misleading details to further help their own cause.  The same "hate the sin, love the sinner" people hating both.

Bottom line is, our society has never been respectable, and the people within it that are, are few and far between.  There is next to nothing that our country has done for anyone but itself, and sadly in a lot of cases people actually enjoy that fact.  Except you forget that, thats why no one likes us, and NO we are not the self-sufficient country you're mislead to think we are.  Something like 85% of our economy relies on IMPORTS from other countries.  If tomorrow everyone said FUCK AMERICA and stopped sending us shit, we'd hit rock bottom within the 24 hour period.  But its not like anyone really wants to stop and think about that when theres new shit at the mall to buy, and 100,000 other things distracting us from the real, disturbing facts.  You can say no one would ever do that, but as long as we keep pushing our ideals on other people, in other countries, we will step closer and closer to that lingering possibility, amongst so many others.

like i said... as everything comes at a cost, so does freedom

..and with freedom, you have the freedom to keep not giving a shit like you've been

for any man with enough reason, speaks on the behalf of the mute.  his words bring solace to some, and others protest and damage his home, burn crosses in his yard, destroy his vehicle.  just a man; a single man turns an idea to a reality with a hard press from his lips to his fellow man.  his most convincing tone, built with a sentiment that should some day exceed the expectations of his silent brothers.

a single man with a voice may possess more power than the body that governs him.  for it is only his silent counterparts that allow his belief that he is powerless.

our history is a series of events based upon those that refused to accept things for which they stood, and through their natural rights; their birth rights, they used their voice and stood with immovable force upon the grounds which best benefited themselves, or their people.

the hand of one man can close pandora's box, and the breath of another may open its wickedness upon the world.  he who most believes he is powerful enough finds his success in his strength alone and uses it for the greater good of man as a whole, not the individual.  for greed only taints a mans honor, and he soon shall face condemnation to a lonesome world of few; the few, of many that share self-importance, and shall never benefit from the other as their greed will not allow of it.  those that govern most, and ineffectively; that protect themselves and harm others, that consider not the single man, but the individual mind he, himself, owns.

it is not the mind itself, but the individual whose purpose best serves his countrymen.  for it is not for one, but for all we shall live, unless a shallow, blackened heart should be preventing and unwilling.

no man shall die in vain without a name, for a cause unjust in his heart, he may choose to oppose a war and his life be spared by his freedoms, and not his fear of force.  he may still be a hero, to some, and others a cowardly, betrayer.  however, a partriot exists not in a war with a foriegn enemy, but a war with his government sought to be unjust, and insufficient.  for a man shall only die on his own terms, and not by a man whose life is protected by his seat in the government, may it be state, or national.

After reading through exerpts of Plato's Republic, I've reached alot of epiphanies just by the general overview of how he interpreted things at such an early time.  To think that someone thought of the society we now have, centuries before it was ever even established, is pretty mind blowing.  At first it was almost hard to believe.  Although, clearly flawed to an extent, the ideas and questions it raises I found to be most important.  Aside from gaining the realization that I infact share a great quantity of these ideas with him, amongst other more progressive ideas and changes to what society currently is.  More or less that i've become more of a political philosopher as i've grown older.

Beyond just realizing how early these idea's arose, I've also realized that it took that long for them to ever be realistically established.  This, largely due to the fact of people being so unwilling to accept change.  Well, drastic change atleast.  I think to figure out the ways in which people reject the ideas, or ridicule them would probably be the most appropriate way to find the right approach to presenting them to society.     -We have technologically advanced so quickly within the last decade, that we've flooded the market with tons of useless shit.  Alot of people forget about the ".com" year(s) where tons and tons of ".com" companies flooded the market in hopes of taking advantage of the new industry trying to create new and innovative ways to do things. (ebay, priceline, etc)  In just that year hundreds upon hundreds of these companies formed.  A year later more than 3/4 of them went bankrupt and failed miserably.  The failure that not only probably cost the people running these companies money, but the loss of employment, and possibly those whom invested money on these companies in the market with the same hope of taking advantage of the new 'boom'.
We have the freedom to do almost anything with our lives, but for the ways in which we've advanced we have undoubtedly put ourselves at a great disadvantage that will grow into the future until be basically regress.
   -Our problem is how gluttonous we have grown through our countries progression, when never taking into consideration the future, except thinking higher and higher.  Bigger and better.  More advanced and unimagineable.  But this is never taking into consideration all the other realities that still exist.  The growing poverty rate, and dimishing middle class, which puts great distance between the rich and those below them.  Our money slowly declining in value, so that we cannot afford to live our lives inexpensively.  The more we create, the more responsibilities we take on, and I think it has become clear that at this current stage we're completely unable to uphold these new obligations, along with the old, and progress as a society.  Nothing lasts forever, and I think we're getting a taste of that reality.
   -Another important point is the fact we have become so arrogant, and completely inconsiderate ever since September 11th.  Patriotism spread like an infectious disease throughout everyone.  Theres nothing wrong with loving your country, and supporting it.  That's not the point.  The point, is that we allowed our patriotism to show how completely incompetent, and uneducated people typcially are.  People prancing around with pride, and their american flags wrapped around them screaming "NUKE EM ALL."  This idea, maybe exaggerated by some, but many say this with dignity, and feel like it's such a great idea, or even the best resolution to our problems.  Firstly, our whole problem to begin with was a group of terrorists, and people without any moral rationality, or respect for human life, in order to send a message and wage war.  What justifies the fact we kill other people with exactly what we, ourselves fear?  Think about during the cold war when schools would have drills, telling children to climb under desks in a pathetic attempt to save themselves from the destruction of a nuclear bombing?  Think about the way that must have felt, the fear it instilled in children, and people as a whole.  That threat that someone might try and kill massive quantities of people with nuclear weapons.  Then ask yourself if by "NUKING EM ALL" it would serve any kind of justice, or just heighten the threat and give people more of a reason to commit these acts of terror, and inhumanities against us.
    -You would think by now people would realize life is not fair, redemption isn't always an option because thats what causes wars.  The entire basis of The Great War (world war 1) was redemption.  Redemption for the assasination of Archduke Francis Ferdinand.  This began what turned into a massive war, a war with a dead rate unimagineable to most.  Old fashioned, and much different than warefare now, yes.  But something so simple as redemption for one single man, caused hundreds of thousands, if not millions to die at war.  Right now, we're in a much larger form of redemption, with much stronger capabilities, and alot more at stake.  We're not considering the modernized form of "pandora's box" we are opening by now proving to have had a baseless war.  We have failed to prove that our cause was just, and factual, and based around the right reasons.  It doesn't matter how much we needed Sadaam out of power, but alot of people don't take into consideration the way these people see our actions.  We see them as beneficial to our country, and "for the best."  To some degree that is entirely correct.  But in another regard we are giving these people more of a reason to come back decades later with a intricately devised plan to cause more havoc and death in America because of it.  It is quite clear these people are willing to wait, and the more we force ourselves on them, and destroy them in return we are just asking for more in return, and the cycle never ends.  ...And it won't.  So if you thought September 11th is bad, just imagine when the attacks worsen with different weaponry, or targets.  (don't be so stupid as to believe they're gonna bomb your childs school of 25 kids in the middle of wyoming.)
   -Our society is completely inept to interpreting the thoughts and feelings of anyone else but ourselves.  We've been bred to trust, and rely on the media to interpret things that are far beyond the black and white print we read, and everything inbetween.  Our whole lives we're trained to believe and trust in authorities and maybe thats alright.  But theres a fine line between listening, and taking things for granted.  For a large part we have lost our focus on critically thinking about the issues in the world without having some sort of media influence in there.  Everything in the media is a portrayal of both imagery, and the use of language.  How it is used, is how we interpret it, and that has become the problem.
